fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.
A limit of a diagram is a universal cone.

By the definition of universal elements, a limit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{lim} D\in C and a cone \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(-, \operatorname *{lim} D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D.
Fully faithful functors reflect extant limits and colimits.

We show the result for limits. Let C\xrightarrow {F} D be fully faithful and let J\xrightarrow {K} C be a diagram in C. Further let z\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Kj be a cone over K in C whose image Fz\xrightarrow {F\lambda _j} FK is limiting in D. Let z'\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Kj be another cone. Then by the universal property of limits in D, there exists a unique map Fz'\xrightarrow {f} Fz commuting with the respective cones. Now by fully faithfulness of F, this map lifts to a unique map z'\to z commuting with the cones, witnessing the universal property of z as a limit of K.

Let I\times J\xrightarrow {F} C be a bifunctorial diagram such that the following limits and colimits exist. Then there is a canonical map \operatorname *{colim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F\to \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{colim}_I F.
In particular, the map goes from a colimit to a limit because colimits are easy to map out of, while limits are easy to map into.

fr:title.text: Map out of colimits, map into limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Map out of colimits, map into limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The universal property of limits makes it easy to construct morphisms into them; the universal property of colimits makes it easy to construct maps out of them.
Let J be an index category and let C be J-complete. Then there is a functor C^J \xrightarrow {\operatorname *{lim}_J} C which acts on functors by taking the limit.
Note that this theorem relies on a choice of witnesses to the completeness of C, i.e. a canonical choice of limit of each J-shaped diagram.
A category is complete if and only if it has all small products and equalizers.
Dually, a category is cocomplete if and only if it has all small coproducts and coequalizers.
The forwards direction is immediate, because products and equalizers are limits.
In the backwards direction, let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a small diagram. Now we define maps c and d using the universal property of the product as follows:

To demonstrate the universal property of the limit, let z\xrightarrow {\mu } F be another cone over F. Then the legs of the cone yield a map z\to \prod _{j\in J} Fj by the universal property of the product. Since it is a cone, hence commutes with Ff, this map equalizes the previous diagram. We obtain the desired result by the universal property of the equalizer.

Let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a diagram in a locally small category C whose limit exists. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(x, \operatorname *{lim} F)\cong \operatorname *{lim} C(x, F-), where the latter is a limit in Set.
Dually, let the colimit of F exist. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} F, x)\cong \operatorname *{lim}_{J^\text {op}} C(F-, x).

fr:title.text: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism of cones. Explicitly, let J\xrightarrow {d} C be a diagram and suppose x\xrightarrow {\lambda } D and y\xrightarrow {\mu } D are both limiting cones. Then there is a unique isomorphism x\to y commuting with the \lambda and \mu .
Dually, colimits are unique up to unique isomorphism of cocones.

This follows from the characterization of representable isomorphism, but we give a direct proof. To show isomorphism, note that the universal property of limits induces a pair of unique maps x\xtofrom [g]{f} y commuting with the cones; it remains to show these are isomorphisms. The composite gf is a map x\to x commuting with the cone \lambda , but 1_x is another such map, so by uniqueness of suchs maps gf = 1_x. The same works on the other side.

fr:title.text: Terminal object › universal property of terminal objects

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Terminal object › universal property of terminal objects

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By the universal property of limits, an object t is terminal in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism c\to t.

fr:title.text: Product › universal property of the product

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product › universal property of the product

fr:title.text: Equalizer › universal property of the equalizer

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equalizer › universal property of the equalizer

fr:title.text: Pullback › universal property of the pullback

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Pullback › universal property of the pullback

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The symbol \lrcorner in the previous diagram denotes that the square is a pullback.

A cone over a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C with apex c\in C is a natural transformation c\xrightarrow {\lambda } D, where c is the constant functor at c. Explicitly, a cone consists of, for each object j\in J, a morphism c\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Dj, so that for each morphism j\xrightarrow {f}k\in J, the following diagram commutes:
The components \lambda _j of the cone are called its legs.
A commutatitive diagram in a category C is a functor J\xrightarrow {D} C. The domain J is called the indexing category or the shape of the diagram.
A limit of a diagram is a universal cone.

By the definition of universal elements, a limit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{lim} D\in C and a cone \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(-, \operatorname *{lim} D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D.
An terminal object is a limit of an empty diagram.
By the universal property of limits, an object t is terminal in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism c\to t.

fr:title.text: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A (covariant) functor C\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements \text {el}(F) has a initial object. Dually, a presheaf C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements has a terminal object.

First let c\in C represent F, so that there is a natural isomorphism C(c, -)\overset {\alpha }{\cong } F. Then the pair (c, \alpha _c(1_c)) is initial in \text {el}(F). Indeed, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), the bijection \alpha _d determines a unique element f\in C(c, d) so that Ff(\alpha _c(1_c)) = y; this exactly expresses initiality.

Conversely, let (c, x) be initial in \text {el}(F). By the Yoneda lemma, the element x\in Fc determines a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\Phi (x)} F; we need to show this is an isomorphism. Initiality of (c, x) asserts that, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), there is a unique map c\xrightarrow {f_y} d such that Ff_y(x) = y. Now in the proof of the Yoneda lemma, \Phi (x) was constructed so that F(\Phi (x)_d)(f) = Ff(x), so the assignment (d, y)\mapsto f_y inverts \Phi (x)_d.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor. The category of elements \text {el}(F) is the comma category *\downarrow F, where *\xrightarrow {*} Set is the inclusion of the point into the singleton set. Explicitly, the category of elements has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, pairs (c, x) where c\in C and x\in Fc;
as morphisms (c, x)\to (d, y), morphisms c\xrightarrow {f} d in C such that Ff(x) = y;
composition and identities inherited from C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The category of elements is further endowed with a forgetful functor \text {el}(F)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C sending (c, x) to c.
